metadata.title: From cutting-edge research to industrial applications with Giotto | by Francesco Palma | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: From cutting-edge research to industrial applications with Giotto
metadata.description: If you are an enterprise data scientist, you ideally want access to the cutting-edge research because the field moves so fast. One of the challenges with this is that integration with the PyData…

all_paragraphs: Written by Diego Fiori, Thomas Boys, Lewis Tunstall, Umberto Lupo and Francesco Palma

If you are an enterprise data scientist, you ideally want access to the cutting-edge research because the field moves so fast. One of the challenges with this is that integration with the PyData stack and machine learning frameworks like scikit-learn is rarely simple.
What does it take to go from cutting-edge research to industrial applications?

Currently, most research in machine learning is published in the form of articles and, in some cases, accompanying code. By design, these codebases are optimized for the specific research application, and it is not always simple to integrate these tools with a wider eco-system.

At L2F, we have launched the Giotto open source project, whose vision is to make advanced machine learning techniques available to the wider data science community. We currently develop two libraries:

In this post, we aim to show how you can take a bleeding-edge technique for graph classification and integrate it with giotto-tda. Specifically, we will integrate recent research and open-source code by Royer et al. at GUDHI/Inria into a giotto-tda pipeline.
GitHub repo for the automatic extraction of topological features on graphs (example below on molecule toxicology classification)

The algorithm introduction by Royer et al. is called ATOL, for Automatic Topologically-Oriented Learning. It addresses a key problem in topological data analysis (TDA), namely the automatic extraction of features from so-called persistence diagrams. A persistence diagram is a representation of the global topology of a dataset in terms of its connectivity at all scales simultaneously — it is obtained by progressively connecting neighbouring points and recording the evolution of the “homology” of the construction. It is a new way to understand, visualize and extract features from data.
For a general introduction to topological machine learning, persistent homology/persistence diagrams, and how to use giotto-tda within your ML pipelines you can refer to this blog post.

Tight integration with scikit-learn is one of the key design principles behind giotto-tda. This makes it simple to implement custom components for your own project that interact with scikit-learn pipelines, meta-estimators, and model selection tools such as grid search.

Let’s warm up by considering the transformer template provided by scikit-learn. From the template, we see that there are three essential components that we need to implement to create a custom transformer: the constructor “_init_”, the “fit” and the “transform”.

Transformers are special kinds of estimators. An estimator is an object that fits a model based on some training data. All estimators implement the “fit” method which stores the estimated model in public or private attributes:

When creating an object, you will want to define an instantiation method which defines the default parameters of the object. The __init__method should only define hyper-parameters of your model which are independent of training data.

What sets transformers apart from general estimators is that they should also implement a “transform” method for filtering or modifying data. The data passed to “transform” can be different to the data used to fit the model, and information learned in “fit” can be used in “transform” — typically, this is the case in supervised or unsupervised statistical learning!

In the case of ATOL, the authors of the original code already defined a transformer class Atol here (retrieved 21/01/2020). As you can see, it implements “fit” and “transform” methods. The main role of “fit” is to store cluster centers computed by a run of the KMeans algorithm on a collection of persistence diagrams, while “transform” can be applied to a single unseen persistence diagram to yield a vector representation.

This Atol class is close to being directly usable in a machine learning framework, but it has a key drawback: if your data problem yields collections of persistence diagrams, you will probably want the “transform” method to be able to act on collections of persistence diagrams too. This is typical for scikit-learn transformers, and key for things like model validation.

This, together with other small changes aimed at making the Atol transformer more compliant with scikit-learn’s contributing guidelines, is why we put together a slightly modified version of this class here. Below is the new transform method. It acts on a collection X of diagrams by calling the “transform_single_diag” method on each element of the collection.

Experts will notice another technical difference, which is tied with giotto-tda’s unique ability to expose different “homology dimensions” separately to the user (and hence to apply Atol independently to each).

One of the common challenges with integrating persistence diagrams with machine learning is the need to vectorize the diagrams into feature vectors. Over the years, a variety of proposals have been put forth. Several ad-hoc vectorisation methods are widely used by the community and many of these are implemented in giotto-tda! However, it remains a challenging research problem to find robust ways to automatically learn task-specific vector representations.
To address this, Royer et al. have recently proposed a novelalgorithm to automatically vectorise persistence diagrams. ATOL based on the following steps:

Graph classification is a core machine learning task that can be used to determine the toxicity of molecules, or not, or classify members of a social network into one or more categories. The observations are complete graphs and the goal is to predict which category they belong to.
Chemistry and graphs, they are a bit like hand and glove: made for each other. Fun fact, the term graph itself first figured in a 1878 Nature paper, vulgarizing algebra’s application to…chemistry.
GitHub repo for toxicology classification with TDA
To work their magic, machine learning algorithms require the input to be in numerical form. To learn on graphs, we thus need a way to encode their structure numerically.
Graphs encode a very basic notion of relationship between entities, which makes them very flexible objects. However, only in their numerical representation can we do machine learning on them.

Two very similar looking graphs can in practice have a lot of differences. Distances between graphs express to what extend we consider little differences between graphs, and are computed on their numerical representation.
Graphs can be characterized by the robustness of their path network.

The resilience of the path network to removing an edge or two is measured in terms of the creation of disconnected regions. Removing one or two random edges in graphs 0 and 1 will constrain your ability to freely travel from node to node, as some points will disjoint from the rest, whereas there is no chance this would happen in graphs 4 or 6.
Out of all data structures you can think of, graphs are the most likely to have some notions of topology.

The HKS algorithm (Heat Kernel Signature) studies how components of the graph merge as you add or remove edges from the graph. After fixing a parameter t, it outputs two persistence diagrams for each H₀ and H₁. We run HKS for t=0.1 and t=10 and have 8 diagrams to describe the graph.

The ATOL algorithm then produces a feature vector based on the collection of N persistence diagrams. After fixing a number of clusters b, Atol outputs a feature vector of size N*b. We run HKS for b=2, which produces 8*2=16 coordinates.
Based on a collection of 1478 molecules labeled safe or toxic (with class ratio of 93:7) we build descriptive features from persistence diagrams using ATOL.

The existing benchmark on the dataset achieves 0.995 in AUC with a single deep learning model called TextCNN. We reach a very respectable 0.976 using the features from the molecule and those generated from our pipeline.
More specifically our final XgBoost model has the following features:
It is interesting to note that the ATOL features alone (without chemical information) score 0.72 on the AuRoc.
Co-founder at L2F | Open-source developer @Giotto_ai | Mathematician interested in everything with a topology
